category.text: $module$/top/Default for 8.2 Solution by Inverse Matrix Method

info.text: The default category for questions shared in context '8.2 Solution by Inverse Matrix Method'.

questiontext.text:
Solving a system of two equations using the inverse matrix Løse et system av to likninger ved hjelp av inversmatrisen.

If we have one linear equation \( ax=b\) in which the unknown is \(x\) and \(a\) and \(b\) are constants and \(a\neq 0\) then \(x=\dfrac{b}{a}= a^{-1}b\). Hvis vi har en lineær likning: \( ax=b\) der den ukjente er \(x\) og \(a\) og \(b\) er konstanter og \(a\neq 0\), så er \(x=\dfrac{b}{a}= a^{-1}b\).

What happens if we have more than one equation and more than one unknown? In this worksheet we copy the algebraic solution \(x=a^{-1}b\) used for a single equation to solve a system of linear equations. As we shall see, this will be a very natural way of solving the system if it is first written in matrix form. Hva skjer hvis vi har mer enn én ligning og mer enn én ukjent? I dette arbeidsarket kopierer vi den algebraiske løsningen \(x=a^{-1}b\) som brukes for en enkelt ligning for å løse et lineært ligningssystem. Som vi skal se, vil dette være en veldig naturlig måte å løse systemet på hvis det først er skrevet i matriseform.

Consider the system \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2&= & 5 \\ x_1 & - & 2x_2&= & -1. \end{matrix} \] In matrix form this becomes \[\qquad \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c}x_1\\ x_2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}5\\ -1\end{array}\right]\ \ \quad\text{which is of the form}\ \quad AX=B.\] Vurder systemet \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2&= & 5 \\ x_1 & - & 2x_2&= & -1. \end{matrix} \] I matriseform blir dette \[\qquad \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c}x_1\\ x_2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}5\\ -1\end{array}\right]\ \ \quad\text{som er av formen}\ \quad AX=B.\]

If \(A^{-1}\) exists then the solution is \[\qquad X=A^{-1}B.\qquad\text{(compare the solution} \ x=a^{-1}b \ \text{above)}\] Hvis \(A^{-1}\) eksisterer, så er løsningen \[\qquad X=A^{-1}B.\qquad\text{(sammenlign løsningen} \ x=a^{-1}b \ \text{over)}\]

Example Eksempel

Given the matrix \[A=\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\] find its determinant. What does this tell you about \(A^{-1}\)? Gitt matrisen \[A=\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\1&-2\end{array}\right]\] finn determinantet. Hva forteller dette deg om \(A^{-1}\)?

Solution Løsning

\[|A|=2\times (-2)-1\times 3=-7.\] Since \(|A|\neq 0\) then \(A^{-1}\) exists. Therefore, we can now find \(A^{-1}\): \[|A|=2\times (-2)-1\times 3=-7.\] Siden \(|A|\neq 0\) eksisterer \(A^{-1}\). Derfor kan vi finne \(A^{-1}\):

\[A^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{(-7)}\left[\begin{array}{rr}-2&-3\\ -1&2\end{array}\right]=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\] \[A^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{(-7)}\left[\begin{array}{rr}-2&-3\\ -1&2\end{array}\right]=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\]

Example Eksempel.

Solve the system \(AX=B\) where \[A=\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right], \hspace{2mm} B = \left[\begin{array}{r}5\\ -1\end{array}\right].\] Løs systemet \(AX=B\) der \[A=\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right], \hspace{2mm} B = \left[\begin{array}{r}5\\ -1\end{array}\right].\]

Solution Løsning

In the previous example, we checked that \(A\) has an inverse and computed it. Therefore, \[X=A^{-1}B=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 5\\ -1\end{array}\right]=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{c}7\\ 7\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ 1\end{array}\right].\] I det forrige eksempelet sjekket vi at \(A\) har en invers og beregnet den. Derfor er \[X=A^{-1}B=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{rr}2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{r} 5\\ -1\end{array}\right]=\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{array}{c}7\\ 7\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ 1\end{array}\right].\]

Hence \(x_1=1,\ x_2=1.\) Dermed er \(x_1=1,\ x_2=1.\)

Example Eksempel

Use the inverse matrix method to solve \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 3 \\ 5x_1 & + & 4x_2 & = & 11 \\ \end{matrix} \] Bruk metoden for inversmatrisen til å løse \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 3 \\ 5x_1 & + & 4x_2 & = & 11 \\ \end{matrix} \]

Solution Løsning

The system in \(AX=B\) form is \[\left[\begin{matrix}2&3\\5&4\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}x_1\\x_2\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix}3\\11\end{matrix}\right] . \] We have \(|A|=2\times 4-3\times 5=-7 \neq 0\) and therefore \(A^{-1}\) exists. We can now compute \[A^{-1}=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}4&-3\\-5&2\end{matrix}\right] . \] Using \(X=A^{-1}B\), we have \[X=\left[\begin{matrix}x_1\\x_2\end{matrix}\right]=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}4&-3\\-5&2\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}3\\11\end{matrix}\right]=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}4\times 3-3\times 11\\-5\times 3+2\times 11\end{matrix}\right]=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}-21\\7\end{matrix}\right]= \left[\begin{matrix}3\\-1\end{matrix}\right] .\] Therefore, \(x_1=3,\ x_2=-1\). Systemet i \(AX=B\)-form er \[\left[\begin{matrix}2&3\\5&4\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}x_1\\x_2\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix}3\\11\end{matrix}\right] . \] Vi har \(|A|=2\times 4-3\times 5=-7 \neq 0\) og derfor eksisterer \(A^{-1}\). Vi kan nå regne ut \[A^{-1}=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}4&-3\\-5&2\end{matrix}\right] . \] Ved å bruke \(X=A^{-1}B\) har vi \[X=\left[\begin{matrix}x_1\\x_2\end{matrix}\right]=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}4&-3\\-5&2\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}3\\11\end{matrix}\right]=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}4\times 3-3\times 11\\-5\times 3+2\times 11\end{matrix}\right]=-\dfrac{1}{7}\left[\begin{matrix}-21\\7\end{matrix}\right]= \left[\begin{matrix}3\\-1\end{matrix}\right] .\] Derfor er \(x_1=3,\ x_2=-1\).

name.text: 8.2.1.6 Engineering Example: Currents in two loops

questiontext.text:
Engineering Example: Currents in two loops Teknisk eksempel: Strømmer i to sløyfer

In the circuit shown below find the currents \((i_1,\ i_2)\) in the loops: I kretsen vist nedenfor, finn strømmene \((i_1, i_2)\) i løkkene:

Figure 1 Figur 1


Solution Løsning

We note that the current across the \(3\ \Omega\) resistor (travelling top to bottom in the diagram) is given by \((i_1-i_2)\). With this proviso we can apply Kirchhoff's law: \[\begin{matrix} \text{In the left-hand loop} & 3(i_1-i_2)+5i_1=3 & \rightarrow & 8i_1-3i_2=3 \\ \text{In the right-hand loop} & 3(i_2-i_1)+6i_2=4 & \rightarrow & -3i_1+9i_2=4 \\ \end{matrix}\] Vi merker oss at strømmen over \(3\ \Omega\) motstanden (som går fra topp til bunn i diagrammet) er gitt ved \((i_1-i_2)\). Med dette kan vi anvende Kirchhoffs lov: \[\begin{matrix} \text{I venstre løkke} & 3(i_1-i_2)+5i_1=3 & \rightarrow & 8i_1-3i_2=3 \\ \text{I høyre løkke} & 3(i_2-i_1)+6i_2=4 & \rightarrow & -3i_1+9i_2=4 \\ \end{matrix}\]

In matrix form: \[\left[ \begin{matrix} 8 & -3\\ -3 & 9 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \left[ \begin{matrix} i_1 \\ i_2 \\ \end{matrix} \right]= \left[\begin{matrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ \end{matrix} \right].\] I matrisform: \[\left[ \begin{matrix} 8 & -3\\ -3 & 9 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \left[ \begin{matrix} i_1 \\ i_2 \\ \end{matrix} \right]= \left[\begin{matrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ \end{matrix} \right].\]

The inverse of \[\left[\begin{matrix}\hfill 8& -3 \\ -3& 9\end{matrix}\right]\] is \[\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}9&3\\3&8\end{matrix}\right]\] so solving gives \[\left[\begin{matrix}i_1\\ i_2\end{matrix}\right]=\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}9&3\\3&8\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}3\\ 4\end{matrix}\right] =\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}39\\ 41\end{matrix}\right]\] so \(\displaystyle{i_1= \frac{39}{63}}\), \(\displaystyle{i_2= \frac{41}{63}}\). Den inverse matrisen til \[\left[\begin{matrix}\hfill 8& -3 \\ -3& 9\end{matrix}\right]\] er \[\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}9&3\\3&8\end{matrix}\right]\] så ved å løse får vi \[\left[\begin{matrix}i_1\\ i_2\end{matrix}\right]=\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}9&3\\3&8\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}3\\ 4\end{matrix}\right] =\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}39\\ 41\end{matrix}\right]\] så \(\displaystyle{i_1= \frac{39}{63}}\), \(\displaystyle{i_2= \frac{41}{63}}\).

Non-unique solutions Ikke-unike løsninger

The key to obtaining a unique solution of the system \(AX=B\) is to find \(A^{-1}\). What happens when \(A^{-1}\) does not exist? Nøkkelen til å oppnå en unik løsning av systemet \(AX=B\) er å finne \(A^{-1}\). Hva skjer når \(A^{-1}\) ikke eksisterer?

Consider the system \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 5 & \qquad(1) \\ 4x_1& + & 6x_2 & = & 10 & \qquad (2) \\ \end{matrix}\] In matrix form this becomes \[\left[\begin{matrix} 2&3\\ 4&6\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} x_1\\ x_2\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix} 5\\ 10\end{matrix}\right].\] Vi ser på systemet \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 5 & \qquad(1) \\ 4x_1& + & 6x_2 & = & 10 & \qquad (2) \\ \end{matrix}\] som kan skrives på matriseform som \[\left[\begin{matrix} 2&3\\ 4&6\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} x_1\\ x_2\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix} 5\\ 10\end{matrix}\right].\]

Example Eksempel

Identify the matrix \(A\) and hence find \(A^{-1}\) if it exists. Identifiser matrisen \(A\) og finn \(A^{-1}\) hvis den eksisterer.

Solution Løsning

\[A=\left[\begin{matrix} 2 & 3\\ 4 & 6 \end{matrix}\right]\] and \(|A|=2\times 6-4 \times 3=0.\) Hence \(A^{-1}\) does not exist. \[A=\left[\begin{matrix} 2 & 3\\ 4 & 6 \end{matrix}\right]\] og \(|A|=2\times 6-4 \times 3=0.\) Derfor eksisterer ikke \(A^{-1}.\)

Looking at the original system we see that Equation (2) is simply Equation (1) with all coefficients doubled. In effect we have only one equation for the two unknowns \(x_1\) and \(x_2\). The equations are consistent and have infinitely many solutions. Når vi ser på det opprinnelige systemet, ser vi at ligning (2) er ligning (1) med alle koeffisienter fordoblet. Effektivt sett har vi bare én ligning for de to ukjente \(x_1\) og \(x_2\). Ligningene er konsistente og har uendelig mange løsninger.

If we let \(x_2\) assume a particular value, \(t\) say, then \(x_1\) must take the value \(x_1=\dfrac{1}{2}(5-3t)\), i.e., the solution to the given equations is: Hvis vi lar \(x_2\) ha en bestemt verdi, si \(t\), så må \(x_1\) ta verdien \(x_1=\dfrac{1}{2}(5-3t)\), dvs. løsningen på de gitte likningene er:

\[x_2=t,\qquad x_1=\dfrac{1}{2}(5-3t)\] where \(t\) is called a parameter. \[x_2=t,\qquad x_1=\dfrac{1}{2}(5-3t)\] hvor \(t\) kalles en parameter.

For each value of \(t\) there are unique values for \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) which satisfy the original system of equations. For example, if \(t=1\), then \(x_2=1\), \(x_1=1\), if \(t=-3\) then \(x_2=-3\), \(x_1=7\) and so on. For hver verdi av \(t\) er det unike verdier for \(x_1\) og \(x_2\) som tilfredsstiller det opprinnelige ligningssystemet. For eksempel, hvis \(t=1\), da er \(x_2=1\), \(x_1=1\), hvis \(t=-3\) så er \(x_2=-3\), \(x_1=7\) og så videre.

We can think of the initial problem as finding a point of intersection of the lines given by the equations. Equation (2) is simply equation (1) multiplied by \(2\) and describes the same line. Every point on the line is a point of intersection. Vi kan tenke på den opprinnelige problemstillingen som å finne et skjæringspunkt mellom linjene gitt av ligningene. Ligning (2) er rett og slett ligning (1) multiplisert med \(2\) og beskriver samme linje. Hvert punkt på linjen er et skjæringspunkt.


Now consider the system \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 5 & \qquad (3) \\ 4x_1 & + & 6x_2 & = & 9 & \qquad (4)\\ \end{matrix}\] Since the left-hand sides are the same as those in the previous system then \(A\) is the same and again \(A^{-1}\) does not exist. There is no solution to the Equations (3) and (4). Nå skal vi se på systemet \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2 & = & 5 & \qquad (3) \\ 4x_1 & + & 6x_2 & = & 9 & \qquad (4)\\ \end{matrix}\] Siden venstresidene er de samme som i det forrige systemet, er \(A\) det samme, og igjen eksisterer ikke \(A^{-1}\). Det finnes ingen løsning for likningene (3) og (4).

Indeed, if we double Equation (3) we obtain \[4x_1+6x_2=10\] which conflicts with Equation (4). There are thus no solutions to (3) and (4) and the equations are said to be inconsistent. Hvis vi dobler likning (3), får vi \[4x_1+6x_2=10\] som strider mot likning (4). Det finnes derfor ingen løsninger for (3) og (4), og likningene sies å være inkonsistente.

Thinking of the geometry, the problem is now to find the intersection of two different but parallel lines. Of course such parallel lines will never meet so there are no points of intersection. Ved å tenke på geometrien er problemet nå å finne skjæringspunktet til to forskjellige, men parallelle linjer. Selvfølgelig vil slike parallelle linjer aldri møtes, så det finnes ingen skjæringspunkter.

name.text: 8.2.3.1 Example 3x3 linear system inverse matrix method

questiontext.text:
Solving three equations in three unknowns Løse tre ligninger med tre ukjente.

It is much more tedious to use the inverse matrix to solve a system of three equations although in principle, the method is the same as for two equations. Det er mye mer kjedelig å bruke den inverse matrisen for å løse et system med tre ligninger selv om prinsippet er det samme som for to ligninger.

Example Eksempel

Consider the system \[\begin{matrix} x_1 &- & 2x_2 & + & x_3 & = & 3\\ 2x_1 & + & x_2 & - & x_3 & = & 5\\ 3x_1 & - & x_2 & + & 2x_3 & = & 12 \\ \end{matrix}\] Vi ser på systemet \[\begin{matrix} x_1 &- & 2x_2 & + & x_3 & = & 3\\ 2x_1 & + & x_2 & - & x_3 & = & 5\\ 3x_1 & - & x_2 & + & 2x_3 & = & 12 \\ \end{matrix}\]

and its matrix form \(AX = B\). One can find that \(|A|=10\) (check it!). Hence \(A^{-1}\) exists. og matrisen kan skrives som \(AX = B\). Vi kan se at \(|A|=10\) (sjekk det!). Derfor eksisterer \(A^{-1}\).

Solve it using the inverse matrix method. Løs den ved å bruke metoden med inversmatrisen.

Solution Løsning

  1. Find \(A^{-1}\) by the method of determinants. Finn \(A^{-1}\) ved hjelp av metoden av determinanter.

    2. Form the matrix where each element of \(A\) is replaced by its minor: Dann matrisen der hvert element i \(A\) er erstattet av sin minor:

    \(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-1\\ -1&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}2&-1\\ 3&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}2&1\\ 3&-1\end{array}\right|\\ \\ \left|\begin{array}{rr}-2&1\\ -1&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{cc}1&1\\ 3&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-2\\ 3&-1\end{array}\right|\\ \\ \left|\begin{array}{rr}-2&1\\ 1&-1\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-2\\ 2&1\end{array}\right|\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}1&7&-5\\ -3&-1&5\\ 1&-3&5\end{array}\right].\) \(\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-1\\ -1&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}2&-1\\ 3&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}2&1\\ 3&-1\end{array}\right|\\ \\ \left|\begin{array}{rr}-2&1\\ -1&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{cc}1&1\\ 3&2\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-2\\ 3&-1\end{array}\right|\\ \\ \left|\begin{array}{rr}-2&1\\ 1&-1\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right|&\left|\begin{array}{rr}1&-2\\ 2&1\end{array}\right|\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}1&7&-5\\ -3&-1&5\\ 1&-3&5\end{array}\right].\)

    Now use the \(3\times 3\) array of signs to obtain the matrix of cofactors: Bruk nå \(3\times 3\) matrisen for fortegn for å finne matrisen av kofaktorer:

    The array of signs is \[\left[\begin{matrix} +&-&+\\ -&+&-\\ +&-&+ \\ \end{matrix}\right]\] so that we obtain \[\left[\begin{matrix} 1&-7&-5\\ 3&-1&-5\\ 1&3&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\] Matrisen av fortegn er \[\left[\begin{matrix} +&-&+\\ -&+&-\\ +&-&+ \\ \end{matrix}\right]\] slik at vi får \[\left[\begin{matrix} 1&-7&-5\\ 3&-1&-5\\ 1&3&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\]

  2. Transpose this matrix and divide by \(|A|\) to obtain \(A^{-1}\). Transponer denne matrisen og del på \(|A|\) for å få \(A^{-1}\).

    3. Transposing gives \[\left[\begin{matrix} 1&3&1\\ -7&-1&3\\ -5&-5&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\] Finally, \[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{10} \left[\begin{matrix} 1&3&1 \\ -7&-1&3 \\ -5&-5&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\] Transponering gir \[\left[\begin{matrix} 1&3&1\\ -7&-1&3\\ -5&-5&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\] Til slutt, \[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{10} \left[\begin{matrix} 1&3&1 \\ -7&-1&3 \\ -5&-5&5 \\ \end{matrix}\right].\]

  3. Now use \(X=A^{-1} B\) to solve the system of linear equations. Bruk nå \(X=A^{-1} B\) til å løse systemet med lineære ligninger

    4. \[X=\frac{1}{10}\left[\begin{matrix}1&3&1\\ -7&-1&3\\ -5&-5&5\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} 3\\ 5\\ 12\end{matrix}\right]=\frac{1}{10}\left[\begin{matrix}30\\ 10\\ 20\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix} 3\\ 1\\ 2\end{matrix}\right]\] Then \(x_1=3,\ x_2=1,\ x_3=2\).

This approach, and another known as Cramer's rule (which is not covered here) are both rather tedious! The advantage of the inverse matrix method is that we can determine when there is a unique solution and we can operate on matrix equations abstractly, i.e. if we have \(AX+B=C\) and we know that \(A\) has an inverse then we can rewrite \(X=A^{-1}(C-B)\). By this we can simplify a problem algebraically before attempting any calculations.  Denne metoden, og en annen som kalles Cramers regel (som ikke dekkes her) er begge ganske kjedelige! Fordelen med inversmatrise-metoden er at vi kan avgjøre når det finnes en unik løsning og at vi kan operere på matrise-ligninger abstrakt, dvs. hvis vi har \(AX+B=C\) og vi vet at \(A\) har en invers kan vi omskrive dette til \(X=A^{-1}(C-B)\). På denne måten kan vi forenkle et problem algebraisk før vi prøver noen beregninger.

There are cases where the matrix is more simple than a general \(3 \times 3\) matrix due to the presence of zeros. In these cases the calculation will take less time and become more feasible. Det er tilfeller der matrisen er enklere enn en generell \(3 \times 3\) matrise på grunn av tilstedeværelsen av nuller. I disse tilfellene vil beregningen ta mindre tid og bli mer gjennomførbar.

We will soon see Gaussian elimination which is superior method for general matrices. Vi vil snart se Gauss-eliminasjon, som er en overlegen metode for generelle matriser.

name.text: 8.2.3.3 3x3 linear equations with no unique solution

questiontext.text:
Equations with no unique solution Ligninger uten en unik løsning

If \(|A|=0\), \(A^{-1}\) does not exist and therefore it is easy to see that the system of equations has no unique solution. But it is not obvious whether this is because the equations are inconsistent and have no solution or whether they are consistent and have infinitely many solutions. Hvis \(|A|=0\), eksisterer ikke \(A^{-1}\), og det er derfor lett å se at ligningssystemet ikke har en unik løsning. Men det er ikke åpenbart om dette skyldes at likningene er inkonsistente og ikke har noen løsning, eller om de er konsistente og har uendelig mange løsninger.

Example Eksempel

Consider the systems \[\text{(a)}\ \ \ \ \begin{array}{rrrrr}x_1-x_2+x_3&=&4\\ 2x_1+3x_2-2x_3&=&3\\ 3x_1+2x_2-x_3&=&7\end{array} \qquad\ \ \ \text{(b)}\ \ \ \ \begin{array}{rrrrr}x_1-x_2+x_3&=&4\\ 2x_1+3x_2-2x_3&=&3\\ x_1-11x_2+9x_3&=&13\end{array}\] Betragt systemene \[\text{(a)}\ \ \ \ \begin{array}{rrrrr}x_1-x_2+x_3&=&4\\ 2x_1+3x_2-2x_3&=&3\\ 3x_1+2x_2-x_3&=&7\end{array} \qquad\ \ \ \text{(b)}\ \ \ \ \begin{array}{rrrrr}x_1-x_2+x_3&=&4\\ 2x_1+3x_2-2x_3&=&3\\ x_1-11x_2+9x_3&=&13\end{array}\]

  1. In system (a) add the first equation to the second. What does this tell you about the system? I system (a) legg den første ligningen til den andre. Hva forteller dette deg om systemet?

    2. The sum is \(3x_1+2x_2-x_3=7\), which is identical to the third equation. Thus, essentially, there are only two equations \[\begin{matrix} x_1 & - & x_2 & + & x_3 & = & 4 \\ 3x_1 & + & 2x_2 & - & x_3 & = & 7 \\ \end{matrix}\] Now adding these two gives \(4x_1+x_2=11\) or, equivalently, \(x_2=11-4x_1\). Therefore, \[x_3=4-x_1+x_2=4-x_1+11-4x_1=15-5x_1\] Hence if we give \(x_1\) a value, \(t\) say, then \(x_2=11-4t\) and \(x_3=15-5t\). Thus there is an infinite number of solutions (one for each value of \(t\)). Summen er \(3x_1+2x_2-x_3=7\), som er identisk med den tredje ligningen. Dermed er det i essens kun to ligninger: \[\begin{matrix} x_1 & - & x_2 & + & x_3 & = & 4 \\ 3x_1 & + & 2x_2 & - & x_3 & = & 7 \\ \end{matrix}\] Hvis vi legger disse to ligningene sammen, får vi \(4x_1+x_2=11\), eller tilsvarende, \(x_2=11-4x_1\). Derfor er \[x_3=4-x_1+x_2=4-x_1+11-4x_1=15-5x_1\] Hvis vi gir \(x_1\) en verdi, si \(t\), så blir \(x_2=11-4t\) og \(x_3=15-5t\). Dermed er det et uendelig antall løsninger (en for hver verdi av \(t\)).

  2. In system (b) take the combination \( 5 \) times the first equation minus \(2\) times the second equation. What does this tell you about the system? I system (b) lag kombinasjonen \( 5 \) ganger den første ligningen minus \(2\) ganger den andre ligningen. Hva forteller dette deg om systemet?

    3. The combination is \(x_1-11x_2+9x_3=14\), which conflicts with the third equation. There is thus no solution. Kombinasjonen er \(x_1-11x_2+9x_3=14\), som strider med den tredje ligningen. Det finnes derfor ingen løsning.

In practice, systems containing three or more linear equations are best solved by Gauss Elimination. I praksis løses systemer med tre eller flere lineære likninger best ved bruk av Gauss eliminering.

name.text: 8.2.1.5 Exercise 1 2x2 linear system inverse matrix method

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Solve the following linear system of equations using the inverse matrix method: \[\begin{matrix} {@a@} x_1 & + & {@b@} x_2 & = & {@y[1, 1]@} \\ {@c@} x_1 & + & {@d@} x_2 & = & {@y[2, 1]@} \\ \end{matrix}\] Løs følgende lineære ligningssystem ved å bruke den inverse matrisemetoden: \[\begin{matrix} {@a@} x_1 & + & {@b@} x_2 & = & {@y[1, 1]@} \\ {@c@} x_1 & + & {@d@} x_2 & = & {@y[2, 1]@} \\ \end{matrix}\]

\(x =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We first check if \(A \) is invertible by, for instance, computing the determinant. Since \[ \det A = {@determinant(A)@} \neq 0, \] A is invertible. From the equation \(Ax = b\), since \(A \) is invertible, we can obtain the solution using \(x = A^{-1}Ax = A^{-1}b\). Vi sjekker først om \(A \) er inverterbar ved å for eksempel beregne determinanten. Siden \[ \det A = {@determinant(A)@} \neq 0, \] er \(A\) inverterbar. Fra ligningen \(Ax = b\), siden \(A \) er inverterbar, kan vi finne løsningen ved å bruke \(x = A^{-1}Ax = A^{-1}b\).

We compute \(A^{-1} = {@Ainv@}\). Vi beregner \(A^{-1} = {@Ainv@}\).

Finally we find \(x = A^{-1}b = {@Ainv@}\times {@y@}={@ta1@}\). Tilslutt finner vi \(x = A^{-1}b = {@Ainv@}\times {@y@}={@ta1@}\).

truefeedback.text: Your answer is correct, well done! Svaret ditt er riktig, godt gjort!

falsefeedback.text: Your answer doesn't satisfy the linear system of equations. Indeed, at least one of the equations \[ {@a@} x_1 + {@b@} x_2 = {@a@} \cdot ({@ans1[1][1]@}) + {@b@} \cdot ({@ans1[2][1]@}) = {@y[1][1]@} \] or \[ {@c@} x_1 + {@d@} x_2 = {@c@} \cdot ({@ans1[1][1]@}) + {@d@} \cdot ({@ans1[2][1]@}) = {@y[2][1]@} \] is not satisfied. Svaret ditt tilfredsstiller ikke det lineære ligningssystemet. Faktisk opfyller minst en av ligningene ikke \[ {@a@} x_1 + {@b@} x_2 = {@a@} \cdot ({@ans1[1][1]@}) + {@b@} \cdot ({@ans1[2][1]@}) = {@y[1][1]@} \] eller \[ {@c@} x_1 + {@d@} x_2 = {@c@} \cdot ({@ans1[1][1]@}) + {@d@} \cdot ({@ans1[2][1]@}) = {@y[2][1]@} \]

name.text: 8.2.2.2 Exercise 2x2 linear system infinitely many solutions

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Consider the following linear system of equations: \[\begin{matrix} {@eqq1@} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ \end{matrix}\] Betrakt følgende lineære likningssystem: \[\begin{matrix} {@eqq1@} \\ {@eqq2@} \\

  1. Consider the matrix form \(AX = B\) of the system and identify \(A\) Betrakt matriseformen \(AX = B\) av systemet og identifiser \(A\)

    2. \(A=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Find the determinant of \(A\): Finn determinanten til \(A\):

    \(|A| =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

  3. Determine if the system has no solution, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions. Bestem om systemet ikke har noen løsning, en unik løsning, eller uendelig mange løsninger.

    4. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

  4. If it has a unique solution or infinitely many solutions, these are: Hvis det har en unik løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger, så er disse:

    5. \(x =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

    \(y =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

    Give all the solutions if there is more than one. If there are no solutions, fill the gaps for \(x \) and \(y \) with the word null. Gi alle løsningene hvis det er mer enn en. Hvis det ikke er noen løsninger, fyll plassene for \(x \) og \(y \) med ordet null.

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. In matrix form \(AX = B\), the matrix \(A \) is \[ A = {@AA@}.\] I matriseform \(AX = B\), er matrisen \(A \) \[ A = {@AA@}.\]

  2. \( \det A = {@determinant(AA)@} \).

  3. Since the determinant of \(A \) is \( 0 \), we already know that the system has either no solution or infinitely many solutions. Note that if we multiply the first equation by \({@kk@} \) we obtain \[ {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq1)@}) = {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq1)@}) \Leftrightarrow {@expand(kk * lhs(eqq1))@} = {@kk * rhs(eqq1)@} \] which is the second equation. Therefore, the system has infinitely many solutions. Siden determinanten til \(A \) er \( 0 \), vet vi allerede at systemet enten ikke har noen løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger. Legg merke til at hvis vi multipliserer den første ligningen med \({@kk@} \) får vi \[ {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq1)@}) = {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq1)@}) \Leftrightarrow {@expand(kk * lhs(eqq1))@} = {@kk * rhs(eqq1)@} \] som er den andre ligningen. Derfor har systemet uendelig mange løsninger.

  4. Since both equations are equivalent, we can ignore one of them, say the second one. From the first equation, if we set \(y = t \), where \( t \) can be any real number, we obtain all the solutions to the system \[ x = {@xx1@}, \qquad y = {@xx2@}. \] Siden begge ligningene er ekvivalente, kan vi ignorere den ene, så la oss ignorere nummer to. Fra den første ligningen, hvis vi setter \(y = t \), hvor \( t \) kan være et hvilket som helst reelt tall, får vi alle løsningene til systemet \[ x = {@xx1@}, \qquad y = {@xx2@}. \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: /* Create the vector containing the answers */ vecAns : matrix([ans4], [ans5]);

truefeedback.text: (a) Matrix \(A\) correctly identified. (a) Matrise \(A\) korrekt identifisert.

falsefeedback.text: (a) Be careful, matrix \(A\) was not introduced correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (a) Vær forsiktig, matrise \(A\) ble ikke introdusert riktig. Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (b) Determinant of \(A\) correctly computed. (b) Determinant til \(A\) korrekt beregnet.

falsefeedback.text: (b) Be careful, the determinant of \(A\) was not computed correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (b) Vær forsiktig, determinanten til \(A\) ble ikke beregnet riktig. Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was identified correctly. (c) Dimensjonen til løsningsrommet ble korrekt identifisert.

falsefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was not identified correctly. What happens if we multiply the first equation by \( {@kk@} \)? Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (c) Dimensjonen til løsningsrommet ble ikke identifisert riktig. Hva skjer hvis vi multipliserer den første ligningen med \( {@kk@} \)? Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (d) You've identified all the solutions correctly (d) Du har identifisert alle løsningene riktig

falsefeedback.text: (d) Your answer satisfies the equation, but is not fully general. You need to add in a constant to represent the general solution. (d) Svaret ditt tilfredsstiller ligningen, men er ikke helt generelt. Du må legge til en konstant for å representere den generelle løsningen.
(d) Your answer does not solve the equation \[ {@AA@}{@vecAns@} = {@BB@}.\] (d) Svaret ditt løser ikke ligningen \[ {@AA@}{@vecAns@} = {@BB@}.\]

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Consider the following linear system of equations: \[\begin{matrix} \displaystyle{{@eqq1@}} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ \end{matrix}\] Betrakt følgende lineære likningssystem: \[\begin{matrix} \displaystyle{{@eqq1@}} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ \end{matrix}\]

  1. Consider the matrix form \(AX = B\) of the system and identify \(A\) Betrakt matriseformen \(AX = B\) av systemet og identifiser \(A\)

    2. \(A=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Find the determinant of \(A\): Finn determinanten til \(A\):

    \(|A| =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

  3. Determine if the system has no solution, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions. Bestem om systemet ikke har noen løsning, en unik løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger.

    4. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

  4. If it has a unique solution or infinitely many solutions, these are: Hvis det har en unik løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger, så er disse:

    5. \(x =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

    \(y =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

    Give all the solutions if there is more than one. If there are no solutions, fill the gaps for \(x \) and \(y \) with the word null. Gi alle løsningene hvis det er mer enn en. Hvis det ikke er noen løsninger, fyll plassene for \(x \) og \(y \) med ordet null.

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. In matrix form \(AX = B\), the matrix \(A \) is \[ A = {@AA@}.\] I matriseform \(AX = B\), er matrisen \(A \) \[ A = {@AA@}.\]

  2. \( \det A = {@determinant(AA)@} \).

  3. Since the determinant of \(A \) is \( 0 \), we already know that the system has either no solution or infinitely many solutions. Note that if we multiply the first equation by \({@kk@} \) we obtain \[ {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq1)@}) = {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq1)@}) \Leftrightarrow {@expand(kk * lhs(eqq1))@} = {@kk * rhs(eqq1)@} \] which is in conflict with the second equation. Therefore, the system is incompatible, i.e., there are no solutions. Siden determinanten til \(A \) er \( 0 \), vet vi allerede at systemet enten ikke har noen løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger. Legg merke til at hvis vi multipliserer den første ligningen med \({@kk@} \) får vi \[ {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq1)@}) = {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq1)@}) \Leftrightarrow {@expand(kk * lhs(eqq1))@} = {@kk * rhs(eqq1)@} \] som er i konflikt med den andre ligningen. Derfor er systemet uforenlig, dvs. det er ingen løsninger.

  4. We have already found that there are no solutions to this system. As indicated in the question, you should enter the word null in both \(x \) and \(y \) as an answer to this part. Vi har allerede funnet at det ikke er noen løsninger til dette systemet. Som angitt i spørsmålet, bør du skrive inn ordet null i både \(x \) og \(y \) som svar på denne delen.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: /* Create the vector containing the answers */ vecAns : matrix([ans4], [ans5]);

truefeedback.text: (a) Matrix \(A\) correctly identified. (a) Matrise \(A\) korrekt identifisert.

falsefeedback.text: (a) Be careful, matrix \(A\) was not introduced correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (a) Vær forsiktig, matrise \(A\) ble ikke introdusert riktig. Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (b) Determinant of \(A\) correctly computed. (b) Determinant til \(A\) er korrekt beregnet.

falsefeedback.text: (b) Be careful, the determinant of \(A\) was not computed correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (b) Vær forsiktig, determinanten til \(A\) ble ikke beregnet riktig. Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was identified correctly. (c) Dimensjonen til løsningsrommet ble korrekt identifisert.

falsefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was not identified correctly. What happens if we multiply the first equation by \( {@kk@} \)? Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (c) Dimensjonen til løsningsrommet ble ikke identifisert riktig. Hva skjer hvis vi multipliserer den første ligningen med \( {@kk@} \)? Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

(d) Careful, as indicated in the question, if you think there is no solution, please fill in the entries for \( x \) and \( y \) with the word null (d) Vær forsiktig, som angitt i spørsmålet, hvis du tror det ikke er noen løsning, fyll inn plassene for \( x \) og \( y \) med ordet null

name.text: 8.2.3.2 Exercise 3x3 linear system inverse matrix method

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Consider the linear system of equations \(AX = B\), where Betrakt det lineære ligningssystemet \(AX = B\), hvor

 \[ A ={@matrixa@}, \hspace{2mm} B = {@BB@}. \]

  1. Find the inverse of \( A\), if it is invertible. Finn den inverse av \( A\), hvis den er inverterbar.
    2. \(A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:Result]]

  2. Solve the system \(AX = B \) using the inverse matrix method. Løs systemet \(AX = B \) ved hjelp av den inverse matrisemetoden.
    3. \(X=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:ans2]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. We find the inverse of \( A \) using the Gauss elimination method (use the determinant method if you prefer). Augment matrix \({\bf A}\) with a 3 by 3 identity matrix: Vi finner inversen til \( A \) ved hjelp av Gauss eliminering metoden (bruk determinant metoden hvis du foretrekker det). Utvid matrisen \({\bf A}\) med en 3 x 3 identitetsmatrise:

    \[{@auga@}\]
    There is +1 in the upper left-hand corner so create 0's below it by adding \({@-mrow2@}\) times row 1 to row 2 and \({@-mrow3@}\) times row 1 to row 3 Det er +1 i øvre venstre hjørne så lag 0'er under den ved å legge til \({@-mrow2@}\) ganger rad 1 til rad 2 og \({@-mrow3@}\) ganger rad 1 til rad 3

    \[{@temp1@}\]
    Now there is +1 in entry [2,2] of the matrix so create 0's above and below it by adding \({@-mr1@}\) times row 2 to row 1 and \({@-mr3@}\) times row 2 to row 3
    \[{@temp2@}\]
    Now there is  +1 in entry [3,3] of the matrix so create 0's above it by adding \({@-mro1@}\) times row 3 to row 1 and \({@-mro2@}\) times row 3 to row 2
    \[{@temp3@}\]
    The left half of this matrix is the identity matrix and the right half is the inverse of \({\bf A}\)     Nå er det +1 i oppføringen [2,2] av matrisen så lag 0'er over og under den ved å legge til \({@-mr1@}\) ganger rad 2 til rad 1 og \({@-mr3@}\) ganger rad 2 til rad 3
    \[{@temp2@}\]
    Nå er det +1 i oppføringen [3,3] av matrisen så lag 0'er over den ved å legge til \({@-mro1@}\) ganger rad 3 til rad 1 og \({@-mro2@}\) ganger rad 3 til rad 2
    \[{@temp3@}\]
    Den venstre halvdelen av denne matrisen er identitetsmatrisen og den høyre halvdelen er inversen til \({\bf A}\)

    Therefore \({\bf A^{-1}} = {@correctanswer@}\) Derfor er \({\bf A^{-1}} = {@correctanswer@}\)

  2. Since \(A \) is invertible, we can apply the inverse matrix method to solve the system of equations. Multiply the matrix equation \(A X = B \) by \(A^{-1} \) from the left to obtain \[ X = A^{-1} A X = A^{-1} B = {@correctanswer@} {@BB@} = {@correctanswer . BB@}. \] Siden \(A \) er inverterbar, kan vi bruke den inverse matrisen metoden for å løse likningssystemet. Multipliser matriselikningen \(A X = B \) med \(A^{-1} \) fra venstre for å få \[ X = A^{-1} A X = A^{-1} B = {@correctanswer@} {@BB@} = {@correctanswer . BB@}. \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: Solution to the system found correctly. Well done! Riktig løsning til systemet funnet. Bra gjort!

falsefeedback.text: Your solution doesn't satisfy the equation \(A X = B \): \[ A X = {@matrixa@} {@ans2@} = {@ matrixa . ans2@} \neq {@BB@} = B. \] Løsningen din tilfredsstiller ikke ligningen \(A X = B \): \[ A X = {@matrixa@} {@ans2@} = {@ matrixa . ans2@} \neq {@BB@} = B. \]

truefeedback.text: (a) Inverse matrix found correctly. (a) Riktig inversmatrise funnet.
(a) This is the original matrix. You need to invert it, if possible! (a) Dette er den opprinnelige matrisen. Du må invertere den, hvis mulig!
(a) The matrix \({\bf A}\) is invertible. (a) Matrisen \({\bf A}\) er inverterbar.
(a) This is the identity matrix. (a) Dette er identitetsmatrisen.

name.text: 8.2.3.4 Exercise 3x3 linear system infinitely many solutions

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øving

Consider the following linear system of equations: \[\begin{matrix} {@eqq1@} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ {@eqq3@} \\ \end{matrix}\] Betrakt følgende lineære likningssystem: \[\begin{matrix} {@eqq1@} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ {@eqq3@} \\

  1. Consider the matrix form \(AX = B\) of the system and identify \(A\) Vurder systemets matriseform \(AX = B\) og identifiser \(A\)

    2. \(A=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Find the determinant of \(A\): Finn determinanten til \(A\):

    \(|A| =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

  3. Determine if the system has no solution, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions. Bestem om systemet ikke har noen løsning, en unik løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger.

    4. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

  4. If it has a unique solution or infinitely many solutions, these are: Hvis den har en unik løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger, er disse:

    5. \(x =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

    \(y =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

    \(z =\) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

    Give all the solutions if there is more than one. If there are no solutions, fill the gaps for \(x, y \) and \(z \) with the word null. Gi alle løsningene hvis det er mer enn én. Hvis det ikke finnes noen løsninger, fyll plassene for \(x, y \) og \(z \) med ordet null.

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. In matrix form \(AX = B\), the matrix \(A \) is \[ A = {@AA@}.\] I matriseform \(AX = B\), er matrisen \(A \) \[ A = {@AA@}.\]

  2. \( \det A = {@determinant(AA)@} \).

  3. Since the determinant of \(A \) is \( 0 \), we already know that the system has either no solution or infinitely many solutions. Note that if we consider the linear combination the first equation plus \({@kk@}\) times the second equation we get \[ {@lhs(eqq1)@} + {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq2)@}) = {@rhs(eqq1)@} + {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq2)@}) \] which becomes \[ {@expand(lhs(eqq1) + kk * lhs(eqq2))@} = {@expand(rhs(eqq1) + kk * rhs(eqq2))@}.\] Note that this is the third equation. Therefore, the system has infinitely many solutions. Siden determinanten til \(A \) er \( 0 \), vet vi allerede at systemet enten ikke har noen løsning eller uendelig mange løsninger. Legg merke til at hvis vi vurderer den lineære kombinasjonen av første ligning pluss \({@kk@}\) ganger den andre ligningen, får vi \[ {@lhs(eqq1)@} + {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq2)@}) = {@rhs(eqq1)@} + {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq2)@}) \] som blir \[ {@expand(lhs(eqq1) + kk * lhs(eqq2))@} = {@expand(rhs(eqq1) + kk * rhs(eqq2))@}.\] Legg merke til at dette er den tredje ligningen. Derfor har systemet uendelig mange løsninger.

  4. Since the third equation is a linear combination of the other two, we can ignore it. Setting \(z = t \), where \( t \) can be any real number, we can obtain all the solutions to the system with \( t \) as a parameter: \[ x = {@xx1@}, \qquad y = {@xx2@}, \qquad z = {@xx3@}. \] You could also have chosen to set \(x = t \) (resp. \(y = t \)), and obtain equivalent expressions. Siden den tredje ligningen er en lineær kombinasjon av de to andre, kan vi ignorere den. Setter vi \(z = t \), der \( t \) kan være et hvilket som helst reelt tall, kan vi få alle løsningene til systemet med \( t \) som en parameter: \[ x = {@xx1@}, \qquad y = {@xx2@}, \qquad z = {@xx3@}. \] Du kunne også ha valgt å sette \(x = t \) (eller \(y = t \)), og fått tilsvarende uttrykk.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: /* Create the vector containing the answers */ vecAns : matrix([ans4], [ans5], [ans6]);

truefeedback.text: (a) Matrix \(A\) correctly identified. (a) Matrise \(A\) korrekt identifisert.

falsefeedback.text: (a) Be careful, matrix \(A\) was not introduced correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (a) Vær forsiktig, matrise \(A\) ble ikke introdusert riktig. Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (b) Determinant of \(A\) correctly computed. (b) Determinant til \(A\) er korrekt beregnet.

falsefeedback.text: (b) Be careful, the determinant of \(A\) was not computed correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (b) Vær forsiktig, determinanten til \(A\) ble ikke beregnet riktig. Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was identified correctly. (c) Dimensjonen til løsningsrommet ble korrekt identifisert.

falsefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was not identified correctly. What happens if we consider the linear combination the first equation plus \({@kk@}\) times the second equation? Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded. (c) Dimensjonen til løsningsrommet ble ikke identifisert riktig. Hva skjer hvis vi betrakter den lineære kombinasjonen av den første ligningen pluss \({@kk@}\) ganger den andre ligningen? Dessverre endret denne feilen problemets vanskelighetsgrad og flere poeng kan ikke tildeles.

truefeedback.text:
(d) You've identified all the solutions correctly (d) Du har identifisert alle løsningene riktig

Well done! Bra gjort!

falsefeedback.text: (d) Your answer satisfies the equation, but is not fully general. You need to add in a constant to represent the general solution. (d) Svaret ditt tilfredsstiller ligningen, men er ikke helt generell. Du må legge til en konstant for å representere den generelle løsningen.
(d) Your answer does not solve the equation \[ {@AA@}{@vecAns@} = {@BB@}.\] (d) Svaret ditt løser ikke ligningen \[ {@AA@}{@vecAns@} = {@BB@}.\]

name.text: 8.2.3.5 Exercise 2x2 linear system no solutions v2 (NOT IN QUIZ)

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Consider the following linear system of equations: \[\begin{matrix} \displaystyle{{@eqq1@}} \\ \displaystyle{{@eqq2@}} \\ \end{matrix}\]

  1. Consider the matrix form \(AX = B\) of the system and identify \(A\)

    2. \(A=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Find the determinant of \(A\):

    \(|A| =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

  3. Determine if the system has no solution, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions.

    4. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

  4. If it has a unique solution or infinitely many solutions, these are:

    5. \(x =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

    \(y =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

    Give all the solutions if there is more than one. If there are no solutions, fill the gaps for \(x \) and \(y \) with the word null.

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. In matrix form \(AX = B\), the matrix \(A \) is \[ A = {@AA@}.\]

  2. \( \det A = {@determinant(AA)@} \).

  3. Since the determinant of \(A \) is \( 0 \), we already know that the system has either no solution or infinitely many solutions. Note that if we multiply the first equation by \({@kk@} \) we obtain \[ {@kk@} \cdot ({@lhs(eqq1)@}) = {@kk@} \cdot ({@rhs(eqq1)@}) \Leftrightarrow {@expand(kk * lhs(eqq1))@} = {@expand(kk * rhs(eqq1))@} \] which is in conflict with the second equation. Therefore, the system is incompatible, i.e., there are no solutions.

  4. We have already found that there are no solutions to this system. As indicated in the question, you should enter the word null in both \(x \) and \(y \) as an answer to this part.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: /* Create the vector containing the answers */ vecAns : matrix([ans4], [ans5]);

truefeedback.text: (a) Matrix \(A\) correctly identified.

falsefeedback.text: (a) Be careful, matrix \(A\) was not introduced correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded.

truefeedback.text: (b) Determinant of \(A\) correctly computed.

falsefeedback.text: (b) Be careful, the determinant of \(A\) was not computed correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded.

truefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was identified correctly.

falsefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was not identified correctly. What happens if we multiply the first equation by \( {@kk@} \)? Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded.
(d) Careful, as indicated in the question, if you think there is no solution, please fill in the entries for \( x \) and \( y \) with the word null

name.text: 8.2.3.6 (not in quiz) Exercise 3x3 linear system inverse matrix method v2

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Consider the linear system of equations \(AX = B\), where

 \[ A ={@matrixa@}, \hspace{2mm} B = {@BB@}. \]

  1. Find the inverse of \( A\), if it is invertible.
    2. \(A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Solve the system \(AX = B \) using the inverse matrix method.
    3. \(X=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

[[feedback:Result]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. We find the inverse of \( A \) using the Gauss elimination method (use the determinant method if you prefer). Augment matrix \({\bf A}\) with a 3 by 3 identity matrix:

    \[{@auga@}\]
    There is  +1 in the upper left-hand corner so create 0's below it by adding \({@-mrow2@}\) times row 1 to row 2 and \({@-mrow3@}\) times row 1 to row 3

    \[{@temp1@}\]
    Now there is  +1 in entry [2,2] of the matrix so create 0's above and below it by adding \({@-mr1@}\) times row 2 to row 1 and \({@-mr3@}\) times row 2 to row 3
    \[{@temp2@}\]
    Now there is  +1 in entry [3,3] of the matrix so create 0's above it by adding \({@-mro1@}\) times row 3 to row 1 and \({@-mro2@}\) times row 3 to row 2
    \[{@temp3@}\]
    The left half of this matrix is the identity matrix and the right half is the inverse of \({\bf A}\)

    Therefore \({\bf A^{-1}} = {@correctanswer@}\)

  2. Since \(A \) is invertible, we can apply the inverse matrix method to solve the system of equations. Multiply the matrix equation \(A X = B \) by \(A^{-1} \) from the left to obtain \[ X = A^{-1} A X = A^{-1} B = {@correctanswer@} {@BB@} = {@correctanswer . BB@}. \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: (a) Inverse matrix found correctly.
(a) This is the original matrix. You need to invert it, if possible!
(a) The matrix \({\bf A}\) is invertible.
(a) This is the identity matrix.
(b) Solution to the system found correctly. Well done!

falsefeedback.text: (b) Your solution doesn't satisfy the equation \(A X = B \): \[ A X = {@matrixa@} {@ans2@} = {@ matrixa . ans2@} \neq {@BB@} = B. \]

name.text: 8.2.3.7 (not in quiz) Exercise 3x3 linear system unique solution

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Consider the following linear system of equations: \[\begin{matrix} {@eqq1@} \\ {@eqq2@} \\ {@eqq3@} \\ \end{matrix}\]

  1. Consider the matrix form \(AX = B\) of the system and identify \(A\)

    2. \(A=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

  2. Find the determinant of \(A\):

    \(|A| =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

  3. Determine if the system has no solution, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions.

    4. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

  4. If it has a unique solution or infinitely many solutions, these are:

    5. \(x =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

    \(y =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

    \(z =\) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

    Give all the solutions if there is more than one. If there are no solutions, fill the gaps for \(x, y \) and \(z \) with the word null.

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. In matrix form \(AX = B\), the matrix \(A \) is \[ A = {@AA@}.\]

  2. \( \det A = {@determinant(AA)@} \).

  3. Since \( \det A = {@determinant(A)@} \neq 0 \), the system has a unique solution. Furthermore, the matrix \(A \) is invertible.

  4. We can compute the inverse of \( A \) \[ A^{-1} = {@inverseAA@} \] and apply the inverse matrix method to solve the system of equations. Multiply the matrix equation \(A X = B \) by \(A^{-1} \) from the left to obtain \[ X = A^{-1} A X = A^{-1} B = {@inverseAA@} {@BB@} = {@inverseAA . BB@}. \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: /* Create the vector containing the answers */ vecAns : matrix([ans4], [ans5], [ans6]);

truefeedback.text: (a) Matrix \(A\) correctly identified.

falsefeedback.text: (a) Be careful, matrix \(A\) was not introduced correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded.

truefeedback.text: (b) Determinant of \(A\) correctly computed.

falsefeedback.text: (b) Be careful, the determinant of \(A\) was not computed correctly. Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded.

truefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was identified correctly.

falsefeedback.text: (c) The dimension of the solution space was not identified correctly. What can we say when the determinant of \( A \) is non-zero? Unfortunately, this error changed the difficulty of the problem and no more points can be awarded.

truefeedback.text:
(d) You've identified all the solutions correctly

Well done!

falsefeedback.text: (d) Your answer does not solve the linear system of equations:  \[ {@AA@}{@vecAns@} = {@AA . vecAns@} \neq {@BB@}.\]
